awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Capacity Planning Methodologies for Large Clusters with Heterogeneous Architectures and Diverse Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on developing innovative techniques and algorithms to build adequate system models and support performance and reliability analysis in order to better explain large system behavior, predict application performance, and ensure high resource efficiency and system dependability. Large cluster environments are an important part of today's computing infrastructure, providing the platform for running applications that handle core business and operational data. However, with the complexity of computing and application infrastructure increasing and the requirements for high quality of service growing, large cluster environments are facing the difficult task of ensuring that applications are always available and delivering adequate performance. This project expects to achieve new capacity planning techniques for performance modeling, workload measurements and model parameterizations of large cluster systems. Intelligent capacity and reliability modeling will enable service providers to determine the best platform for their application before deploying and running the application. It will also enable system managers to optimize the performance, reliability and efficiency of the entire cluster infrastructure.
 
This research will develop new performance modeling methods to capture the characteristics of heterogeneous hardware architectures and predict the behavior of an application running on an array of computing platforms. The research will extend performance modeling to failure awareness. The improved models will enable an accurate prediction of performance and reliability of a complex large-scale system by capturing the characteristics of both system workloads and failure events. In addition, the researchers will develop new advanced techniques to parameterize performance models with essential processing information of computational and communication components. These essential processing information do not only limit to mean values but also include other critical yet complicated features such as resource contention and burstiness symptoms. The project is involved with educational activities reaching out to students from secondary to graduate schools to aggressively motivate students, especially women, towards science and engineering integrating this research into curriculum development and undergraduate research activities.

por.por_cntn:
This research aims to develop innovative techniques and algorithms to build adequate system models and enhance system performance and reliability for large-scale systems, such as datacenters and storage cluster systems. The primary goals of this work include (1) deriving new prediction models and benchmarking methods, (2) leveraging newly evolving processing and storage technologies (such as many core/multicore and flash memory), and (3) making the best usage of system resources (e.g., CPU, memory, and disk resources).

 

Intellectual Merit: The key contributions of this proposal include developing a fundamental understanding of workload and reliability characteristics in datacenters and large-scaled storage systems, providing new performance modeling and benchmarking methods to capture the characteristics of heterogeneous hardware architectures and predict the behavior of an application in a much more accurate manner, making the best use of new and emerging technologies, such as Graphics Processing Units (GPUs) and NAND Flash devices to achieve high performance and high reliability in today and tomorrow's clusters. 

 

 

 

Broader Impact: In this research work, we have devoted the outreach agenda to motivating undergraduate students and minority students in computer science and engineering and developing an education module centered on applications with intensive computing and data access challenges. The PI naturally attracts female students interested in computer engineering as a female faculty. We aggressively motivated young female students toward science and engineering. We constantly participate in the events hosted by the Graduate Women in Science and Engineering (GWISE) at Northeastern and serve on the conference committee for the Women of Color in the Academy Conference, which aims to enhance the timely career progression of female faculty, post-doctoral scholars, and graduate students. The PI also has excellent experience working with female researchers and supporting female students in her research projects. Furthermore, we integrated the research work into curriculum development and undergraduate research activities. This project offers a natural vehicle in place for technology transfer by building collaborations with industries and research labs (e.g., VMware, Samsung) on this project.

 

Project Outcomes:   First, we focus on developing novel performance modeling and benchmarking techniques for accurately predicting the execution time of applications running on distributed systems. We derived a new performance modeling approach, FiM, to predict a data processing application's end-to-end execution time (including computation and communication). One of the key innovations of our work is that FiM relies on only very small datasets for training but can accurately predict the execution times for larger datasets. The derived models can give data analysts quick feedback about the execution time of their data processing and provide optimized implementation regarding application parameters and hardware architectures. We also developed a new benchmarking approach (PatIO) to capture the prevailing enterprise storage behavior across various user workloads, virtualization setups, file systems, and volume managers for the database server applications on flash-based storage. PatIO resembles a wide range of realistic I/O workloads and helps evaluate and configure the variable parameters of emerging storage technologies. 

 

Second, we focus on designing new efficient resource allocation and scheduling algorithms for I/O intensive data processing applications running in distributed data centers with virtualized resources. We proposed a novel approach for opportunistic and efficient resource allocation in resource management platforms (e.g., Hadoop YARN and Mesos) for data processing applications. This approach attempts to break the barriers among the encapsulated resource containers by leveraging the knowledge of actual runtime resource utilization to re-assign available opportunistic resources to the pending tasks. We also designed a new auto-tuning memory manager (ATuMm) and memory allocation scheme (RITA) to support dynamic memory allocation and improve data processing latency in Apache Spark. We further developed new SSD resource management solutions (GREM and AutoReplica), which takes dynamic IO demands of all VMs into consideration to best utilize storage resources and optimize the performance in multi-tiered storage systems.

 

Third, we put significant efforts into leveraging new storage technologies to mitigate I/O bottlenecks in datacenters running data-intensive applications and enhancing the reliability of data centers with SSDs. The technology of multi-stream SSDs was invented to explicitly write different data associated with each other or have a similar lifetime into a single stream. We uncovered the impacts of varying workload features and their combinations on write amplification. We proposed a feature-based stream identification approach (FIOS). FIOS automatically co-relates the measurable workload attributes with high-level workload features and determines the right combination of workload features for assigning streamIDs. We also developed a novel storage infrastructure KV-SiPC, that utilizes the key-value interface to enable the execution of multi-threaded applications on KV-SSDs. KV-SiPC can simplify application data management by removing intermediate layers (e.g., the filesystem and block layers from the OS kernel) and allowing the fine-grained control over interactions of parallel compute and parallel data threads to improve the system concurrency.
